Branches are: ▪ Articular branches ▪ Muscular branches ▪ 2 muscles in the forearm ▪ Palmar cutaneous ▪ Dorsal cutaneous Ulnar NerveArteries of the forearm • Ulnar artery is main artery of forearm • Radial artery is for the hand • Origin: Brachial artery in the cubital fossa 12 Branches of Ulnar artery • Common interosseous: divides into ant. & post. interosseous arteries, & interosseous recurrent • Muscular • Anterior ulnar recurrent – inferior ulnar collateral • Posterior ulnar recurrent – superior ulnar collateral • At wrist – palmar carpal & dorsal carpal • In Palm – superficial palmar arch & deep palmar branch 13 Radial Artery Origin: • Brachial artery in cubital fossa Branches: • Muscular • Radial recurrent • Superficial palmar • At wrist: palmar carpal, dorsal carpal, dorsal metacarpal • In Palm: principal artery of the thump (Arteria princeps pollicis) & Radial artery of index finger (arteria radialis indicis) 14 Carpal TunnelBoundaries of Carpal Tunnel • Roof (Anterior): • Flexor retinaculum (FR) or transverse carpal ligament. Attached: • Medially to pisiform & hook of hamate • Laterally to scaphoid & trapezium • Posterior: • Carpal bones 16 Contents or Structures transmitted • Flexor Pollicis Longus • Flexor Carpi Radialis • (also a content of the roof) • Median Nerve • Anterior interosseous a • Tendons of • Flexor digitorum superficialis • Flexor digitorum profundus • Ulnar and radial bursae 17 Carpal tunnel syndrome: Compression of median nerve in the tunnel thus affecting the distal distribution of the nerve - causing pain, tingling and numbness Ulnar canal (Guyon’s Tunnel) • Boundaries: ❖Hook of hamate ❖Flexor retinaculum • Contents: ❖Ulnar nerve, artery, and vein 18 Ulnar canal syndrome: 1. Hypoesthesia medial 1½ fingers 2. Weakness of intrinsic muscles of hand 3. Inability to flex the ring and little fingers 4. Abducted little finger Anatomical Snuff box Space at radial side of wrist & visible with full extension of thumb. Boundaries • Ulnar side - EPL • Radial side - EPB • Deep – Scaphoid bone Contents • Radial artery • Crossing superficially is superficial branch of radial nerve • Beginning of cephalic vein Wrist (Radiocarpal) Joint • Synovial • Condyloid • Articulation: distal radial condyle, articular disc, proximal carpal bones • Ligament: – Palmar radiocarpal – dorsal radiocarpal – ulnar & radial collateral • Movements: – Flexion, Extension, Abduction (radial deviation), Adduction (ulnar deviation) Joints of the WristIntercarpal Joint • Synovial • Plane • Articulations: btw the carpal bones arranged into rows – Proximal carpal row- less mobile – Distal carpal – less mobile – Mid-carpal – slightly mobile • Ligaments: – interosseous intercarpal – dorsal intercarpal – palmar intercarpal – **flexor retinaculum?? • Movements: – Gliding & sliding producing a range of movements • Abduction-adduction • Flexion-extension • circumduction Carpometacarpal & Intermetacarpal • Synovial • Plane except the thumb (saddle) • Distal surfaces of distal carpals and bases of metacarpals • Ligament: – Palmar and dorsal carpometacarpal and intermetacarpal • Movements: – All fingers- Flexion & Extension, – Thumb – Abduction, Adduction, Opposition, Circumduction Applied Anatomy • Colle’s fracture ➢Most common fracture of forearm ➢Complete transverse fracture of distal 2 cm of radius ➢Distal segment projects posteriorly. http://24.media.tumblr.com/ http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/af/Colles_Fractur.jpg 23 Questions • In a table, list the actions of the muscles in the flexor compartment of the forearm • Write short note on the origin and branches of the ulnar and radial arteries • Write short note on the carpal tunnel and its syndrome • What are the distinguish features between the carpal tunnel and the ulnar (Guyon) tunnel • What are the boundaries and contents of the anatomical snuff box. • Describe the joints in the wrist. 24 Thank you!!! 25
